div.p:
That the faithfull are justified by faith withoist
the lawe and workes.
h Eing readye here
y (dearely beloved) to
speake unto you of
faith, which with
out workes doeth
justifie them that
believe, I call upon
the Father, which is in heaven, tho
rough his onely begotten sonne Jesus
Christ our Lorde, beseeching him to
open my mouth and lippes to the set
ting foorth of his prayse, and to illu
minate your heartes, that ye acknow
ledging the great benefite of God, may
become thankefull for it and holy in
deede.
And first of all, I will speake cer
taine things chiefely necessarie to this
argument or treatise, touching this
terme of justification. The terme of
justifying, very usuall and common a
mong the Hebrews, and of a large sig
nification, is not at this day so wel un
quite from judgement, and from the
denounced and uttered sentence of
condemnation. It signifieth to remit
derstoode of all men, as it ought to be,
To justifie, is as much to saye as to
offences, to cleanse, to sanctifie, and to
give utterance of life everlasting. For
it is a lawe terme belonging to courts
where judgement is exercised. Ima
gine therefore, that man is set before
the judgement seate of God, and that
there he is pleaded guiltie, to wit, that
he is accused and conuinced of heinous
offences, and therefore sued to punish
ment or to the sentence of condemna
tion. Imagine also that the son of God
maketh intercession, and commeth in
as a meane, desiring that uppon him
may be layde the whole fault and pu
nishment due unto us men, that he by
his death may cleanse them and take
them away, setting us free from death
and giving us life everlasting. Ima
gine too, that God the most high and
just judge, receiveth the offer, & tran
slateth the punishment together with
the fault from us unto the necke of his
sonne, making therewiehall a statute
that whosoever beleeveth that ye sonne
of God suffered for the sinnes of the
worlde, brake the polver of death, and
delivered us from damnation, shoulde
be cleansed from his sinnes, and made
heire of life everlasting. Who there
fore can be so dul of understanding, but
may perceive that mankind is iustify
ed by faithe
But that there may be no cause of
doubt of darknesse left in the minde of
any man, that which I have alreadye
spoken generally, by the parable and
similitude fetched from our common
lawe. I wil here particularly bring in
to certaine partes confirming and ma
nifestly proving every one of them se
verally, out of the holy Scriptures, so
that even to the stoutest wits the po
wer of faith and worke of justification,
may be most evident.
And first I wil shew unto you that
this terme of justification, is taken in
this present treatise for the absolution
and remission of sinnes, for sanctificati
on & adoption into the number of the
sonnes of God. In the riii. of the Actes,
the Apostle Paul saith: Be it knowne
into you men and brethren, that
through this Lord lesus Christe, is
preached unto you the foreivenesse of
sinnes, and by him, all that beleeve are
justified from all thinges, from which
they coulde not bee justified by the
lawe of Moses. See, in Christ is prea
ched unto us the forgivenesse of sinnes,
and he that believeth that, Christ prea
ched, and forgiveth sinnes, is also justi
fied. It followeth therfore, that justifi
cation is the remission of sins. In the
fifth Chapter to the Romaines sayeth
the same Apostle. Being justified by
the bloud of Christ, we shal be saved
from wrath through him. But the
bloud of Christ washeth away sinnes,
Justification therefore is the washing
away or forgivenesse of sinnes. And a
gaine, in the second Chapter sayth hee
more plainely, Iudgement entered by
one offence unto condemnation, but
the gift of many sinnes unto justificati
ou. He maketh justificatio the contra
ry to condemnation : therefore, justifi
cation is the absolution and deliverie
from condemnation. What say yee to
this moreover, that hee doeth plainely
call Justification a gift, that is, the for
givenesse of sinnes. Hereunto also be
long those wordes of his, Even as by
the sinne of one, condemnation came
on all men: so by the righteousnesse of
one, good came upon all men to the
justification of lite. Heere againe is
the justification of life made the con
trary of condemnation unto death set
as a peine upon our heades, because of
the transgression: justification of life
therefore is an absolution from sinnes,
a deliverie from death, a quickening
or translating from death to life. For
in the fourth to the Romains, ye same
Apostle expouudeth justification by sa
ctification, and sanctification by the re
mission of sinnes. For intreating of
faith, whereby wee are iustified, or
which God imputeth to us for righte
ousnesse without workes, he saith, E
ven as David also doeth expounde the
blessednesse of that man to whom the
Lord imputeth righteousnes without
works, sayingrblessed are they whose
iniduities are forgiven, and whose sins
are covered.
What coulde bee more plainely
spoken than this: For he doth evident
ly exound justification by sanctificati
on, and sanctification by remission of
sinnes. Furthermore, what else is san
ctification but the adoption whereby
wee are received into the grace and
number of the sonnes of God: What
is hee therefore that seeth not that in
this treatise of saint Paule, justifi
cation is taken for adoption : especial
ly, since in the very same fourth chap
ter to the Bomaines: hee goeth about
to prove, that an inheritance is due to
faith, whereunto also hee doeth attri
bute iustification. By all this it is
made manifest, that the question of
justification containeth nothing else,
but the manner and reason of sanctifi
cation, that is to say, wherby and how
men have their sinnes forgiven, and
are received into the grace & number
of the sonnes of God, and being justifi
ed are made heires of the kingdome of
God.
And now, let us try whether that
which we have saide be taught in the
scriptures, that Christ before the judg
ment seate of God, when sentence of
condemnation was to bee pronounced
against us for our offences, tooke, our
sinnes upon his owne necke, and pur
ged them by the sacrifice of his death
upon the crosse, and that God also laid
upon Christ our fault and punishment,
so that Christ alone is the onely satis
faction and purging of the faithtull,
This doth ye Apostle Paul teach most
expresly, where hee saith: who shall
lay any thing to the charge of Gods
elect) It is God that justifieth. who
shall condemne) It is Christ that dy
ed yea rather it is hee which is raysed
up, and is at the right hande of the fa
ther making intercession for us. And
agayne hee saieth, Christ redeemed us
from the curse of the law, while he was
made the curse for us, For it is written,
cursed be every one that hangeth on
the tree, that upon the Gentiles might
come the blessing of Abraha through
Jesus Christ, &ce, This did the Apostle
teache out of the writinges of Moses,
And Moses in his bookes doeth often
times make mention, that the sins are
laid upo the heads of the beasts which
were facrificed. But those sacrifices
bare the tipe or figure of the death and
facrifice of Christ. Claias also in his g:
chapter saith erpresly, He verily hath
taken on him our insirmities, &t borne
our paines. He was wounded for our
iniduities, and smitten for our sinnes,
For the paine of our punishment was
laid upon him, and with his stripes are
we healed wee all went astray like
sheepe, everie one turned his owne
way, but the Lord hath throwne upon
him all our sinnes. And immediately
after, He hath taken away the sinnes of
the multitude, and made intercession
for the transgressours. Than these
wordes I thinke, nothing canne bee
brought more to the matter, or more
fit for our present purpose. To this al
ludeth S. Peter when hee saieth, The
Lorde himelfe bare our sinnes in his
body uppon the crosse, that we being
dead to sin may live to righteousnesses
by the signe of whose stripes we are
made whole. Hereunto alluded saint
John the forerunner of the Lord, whe
he saide: Behold the Lambe of GOD
that taketh away the sins of the world
Moreover the Apostle Paul heareth
witnesse heereto, saying: Tim that
knewe not sinne, he made sinne for us,
that we through him might be made
the righteousnesse of God. Also in his
Epistle to the Colossians hee sayeth,
It pleased the father that in Christ all
fulnesse shoulde dwell, and by him to
reconcile al thinges unto himelfe, ha
ving set peace through the bloud of his
crosse by him, both things in earth and
thinges in heaven. These I suppose,
are testimonies fufficiently evident,
to prove that upon Christ are laide our
sinnes, with the curse or condemnati
on due unto our offences , and that
Christ by his bloud hath cleansed our
sinnes, and by his death hath vanqui
shed death, and the divel the author of
death, & taken away the punishment
due unto us.
Pet because there be some, and those
not a fewe, which denie that Christ
ners, both fault and punishment, and
that he
by his death hath taken from us sin
of the whole worlde, I will therefore
nowe alledge certaine other testimo
nies and repeat somewhat of that that
I have before recited, thereby to make
it manifest, that Christ the only satis
faction of the worlde, hath made satis
faction both for our fault and punish
ment. Claias verily witnessed, that
both the fault of our offence & the pu
nishment were taken away, when he
saith: Hee hare our infirmities, and
was wounded for our mniduities : fi
nally the discipline of peace, that is, ye
discipline or chastising or punishment
bringing peace, or the penaltie of our
correction, that is, the punishment due
to us for our offences, was layd on his
necke. Marke also what followeth: and
with the blewnesse of his stripes are
we healed.
This doth evidently teach, that by
the paine of Christ our punishment is
taken away. For looke what pain, pe
naltie, punishment, or correction was
due to us, & the same was laide on the
Lord himelfe: and for that cause was
the lord wounded and received stripes.
And with them he healed us. But hee
had not yet healed us at all, if wee
should yet looke for woundes, stripes
and stroakes, that is to say, punishmet
for our sinnes.
The death of Christ therefore is a
full satisfaction for our sinnes. But
what I pray you shoulde Christe a
vayle us, if yet wee shoulde be puni
shed for our offences. Therefore
when we say, that he did beare all our
sinnes in his bodye uppon the Crosse,
what else do wee meane I pray you,
but that the Lorde by death, that was
not due unto him, tooke from us Gods
vengeance, that it might not light on
us to our punishment: Paul, as of
ten as hee maketh mention of our re
demption made by Christ, is wont to
name it arwritmn, by which worde he
understandeth not, as the common
fort do, redemption barely ad simply,
but the verie price and satisfaction of
redemption. Wherefore also hee wri
teth that Christ himelfe did give him
selfe to be the arouren, for us : that is
to say, the price wherewith captives
are redeemed from their enimies in
the warre. For that which we do com
monly call ransomes, the Ereekes do
name wurea. So then that is arrdurni
when man for man and life for life is
redeemed. But upon them that are
thus raunsomed & set at libertie, there
is no punishment afterwarde layd, by
reason of the translation thereof from
one to another. Furthermore, this is
the new covenant ye God in his Christ
hath made with us that he wil not re
memder our iniduities.
But how could he chose but remem
ber our iniquities, if he ceased not to
punish them : So then, this remai
neth not to be doubted of, that Christ
our Lord is the ful portion, satisfacti
on, oblation and sacrifice for the sinnes
I say for the punishment & the fault
of all the worlde, yea and by himelfe
alone : for in none other is any salva
tion: neither is there any other name
given unto men whereby they must
be saved.
I denye not, but that because of dis
cipline, chastisement & erercise, divers
fortes of punishments are layde upon
mens neckes, & that they are diversly
affected & vered, because of their offen
ces. But those afflictions, how soever
they be patiently suffered of the faith,
full, do not yet wash sinnes away, nor
make satisfaction for misdeedes.
S. Peter sayth, Marveyle not that
y are, tryed by fire, which thing is
done for your tryall, as if any newe
thing shoulde happen unto you :
our saviour, God so loved the worlde,
that he gave his only begotten sonne:
that whosoever beleeveth should not
perish, but have life everlasting. For
God sent not his sonne into the world
to condemne the worlde, but that the
worlde through him might be saved.
He that beleeveth on him is not con
demned: but he that beleeveth not, is
condemned alreadie, because he bele
veth not in the name of the onely be
gotten sonne of God. By these words
nowe the thirde time is faith beaten
into our heads, by which we are made
partakers of the sonne of God, of his
life, salvation, redemption, and all good
thinges beside. In the sirt Chapter of
the Gospell after John, our Lorde a
gaine saith: This is the will of the fa
ther which sent mee, that everie one
that seeth the sonne, and beleeveth in
him should have life everlasting, and
I will raise him up at the last day
Nothing can be alledged to make more
for our present argument than these
wordes of his. For he sayth plainely,
that the will of God the father is, that
we should beleeve in the sonne, and
by this beliefe have our salvation.
Whereupon John the Evangelist and
Apostle in his Canonicall Epistle da
reth burst forth into these wordes: He
that beleeveth not God, maketh him
a lyer, because he beleeved not the re
cord that God gave of his sonne. And
this is the recorde, that God hath gi
ven unto us eternall life, and this
life is in his sonne. He that hath the
sonne, hath life: and he that hath not
the sonne of God, hath not life. Deare
ly beloved, note this. The eternall and
unchangeable wil of god is, that he wit
give eternal life unto the worlde. But
he will give the life through Christ,
who is naturally life it selfe, and can
give life. The very same God also wil
yea, rather reioyce herein that ye are
partakers of the afflietions of Christ,
that in the revelation also of his glorie
ye may reioyce and be glad. This I
say, is the ende and use of afflictions.
And by this means the glory of Christ
indureth pure and uncorrupted.
It remaineth now for me to prove
out of the holy Scriptures, that God
the father hath ordeined that he who
soever doth believe in the onely begot
ten sonne of God, shall be made parta
ker of Christ his righteousnesse, that
is, shal be justified by him, be absolved
from his sinnes, and bee made heire of
life everlasting. Claias therfore saith,
In the acknowledging of him, or in
his knowledge shall my righteous ser
vaunt justifie the mulritude, whose
sinnes he himelfe shall beare. But
what else is the acknowledging or
knowledge of Christ, but true faith,
Moreover, the Lord Jesus himselfe
in the Gospell after saint John, saith:
And as Moses lifte up the Serpent in
the wildernes, even so must the sonne
of man be lift up, that whosoever be
leeveth in him, should not perish but
have life everlasting. There was
none other remedy in ye desart, against
the envenomed bytinges of the Ser
pents, but the contemplation or behol
ding of the Serpent lift up and hanged
aloft. No plaster did cure them that
were poysoned, no oblatio made to god,
not praier it selfe offered to God, not a
ny worke, nor any way else : the onely
beholding of the serpent made the poy
son harmlesse, that then had crept into
al their lims. In likemaner, nothing at
all doth save us from death but onelie
faith in Christ.
For by faith we behold and see Christ
lifted up upon the stake of the Crosse,
as it is to beeseene in the sirte chapter
of John. It followeth in the words of
that we obtaine and have life in us,
and that wee have it no other wayes
than by faith. For the Apostle Paule
taught, that Christ doeth dwell in our
hearts by faith. Moreover, the Lorde
hiself also witnesseth & saith: He that
eateth me shall live by mnee. But yee
knowe (dearely beloved) that to eate
Christ is to believe in him. And there
fore we knit up this place with these
wordes of sainct Peter. To this
Christe doe all the Prophetes beare
witnesse, that whosoever beleeveth in
him, shall receive forgivenes of sinnes
through his name. We have in these
a most ample testimonie of the whole
sacred Scriptures. By these I have
evidently enough declared, that God
hath appointed, that whosoever doth
believe in Christ, being clensed from his
sins, shall be made heire of life everla
sting. This will I make more evident
yet, by declaring how that faith alone
that is, that faith for it selfe, and not
for any workes of ours doeth justifie
the faithtull. For it selfe I saye, not
in respect that it is in us a qualitie of
the minde, or our owne worke in our
selves, but in respecte that faith is
the gift of Gods grace, having in it a
promise of righteousnesse and life : and
in respect, that naturally of it selfe, it
is a certaine and undoubted perswa
sion resting upon GOD, and beleeving
that GOD being pacified by Christ,
hath through Christe bestowed life
and all good things on us. Therefore
faith for Christ, and by the grace and
promise of God doth justifie. and so
faith, that is that, which we believe
and wherein our confidence is setled,
God I say himselfe by the grace of god
doth justifie us through our redempti
on in Christ : so that nowe, our owne
workes or merites have no place lefte
to them at al, I mean, in justification,
For otherwise good workes have their
place in the faithtul, as we in place co
venient do meane to shew. For Paul ye
teacher of the Gentils, doth in the way
of opposition compare Christ with A
dam, and sheweth, that of Adam and so
of our owne nature and strength, wee
have nothing but sinne, the wrath of
God, and death,
And this doth hee shewe under the
name of Adam to the intent that no
man should seeke for righteousnes and
life in the fleshe. And againe, on the
other side he declareth, ye we by Christ
have righteousnesse, the grace of God,
life and the forgivenesse of all our sins,
In this opposition, hee doth earnestly
urge and often repeate this worde, of
one, to no other ende verily, but ye we
shuld understand, that faith alone doth
justifie,
To the Galathians hee doth verie
evidently use this kinde of argument,
To the last will and testament of a
man, it it once be proved, no bodie doth
adde or take any thing away. Reason
therefore doth rightly require that no
man put too, or take away any thing
from the testament of God. But this
is the testament which God confirmed
that his will is to bestowe the belessing
upon Abrahams seede, not in many, or
by manie, but through one. For hee
saith not, and to the seedes, as though
he spake of manie, but as speaking of
one he saith, And to thy seede, that is
Christ. Therefore it is a detestalbe
thing to augmet or diminish any thing
in this testament of God: Christ alone
is the onely savour still: men can nei
ther save themselves nor other
Againe, in the same Epistle to the
Galathians he saith: we knowe that
man is not iustified by the workes of
the lawe, but by faith in lesus Christ :
in so muth as no flesh shall be justifi
self, doth digge up the knowledge of of
fences, that is, doth apply them, bring
them to light, and make them mani
fest, but doth not take them away, blot
them out, or utterly extinguish them
and that therefore, GOD for his own
goodnes sake, to the end that the worke
that he hath made, should not altoge
ther perish, doth justifie the faithfull
freely by faith in Jesus Christ. I will
rehearse a fewe of the Apostles owne
wordes. The righteousnesse of God
saith he )is declared without the law,
being witnessed notwithstanding by
the lawe and the Prophets, the righte
ousnesse of God, I saye, commeth by
faith in lesus Christ unto all, et uppon
all them that beleeve. For there is no
difference. For all have sinned et have
neede of the glorie of God: but are iu
stified freely by his grace through the
redemption that is in Christ lesu, who
God hath set forth to be a propitiation
through faith in his bloud. These
words of ye Apostle, I suppose, are most
manifest to them that believe. He plue
keth justification from our owne me
rites & strength, and attributeth it to
grace, wherby the sonne of God is give
to the worlde, unto the punishment of
the Crosse, that all they ye believe that
they are redeemed by the bloud of the
sonne of God, may be justified. Againe
the Apostle immediatly after, addeth:
Therefore we holde that man is iustifi
ed by faith without the workes of the
law. Apon the necke of this againe, he
argueth this. Is he the God of the le
wes onlyy Is he not also of the centilsy
Tes even of the gentiles also. For it is
one God that shall justifie Circumci
sion by faith, and uncireumeision
through faith. To be God, is nothing
else but to be life & salvation. But God
is the God of the Gentiles also, & not of
the Jewes alone: therefore God is the
ed by the workes of the lawe. This is
nowe the thiroe time that Paule saith
that men are not justified by the works
of the lawe. In the which clause hee
comprehendeth all maner of works of
what fort soever. So then, no kinde
of workes doe justifie. But what is it
then that justifieth: Faith in Christ,
and that verily alone. For what else
can these wordes import, we knowe
that man is not iustified but by faith
in Christ. For the force of these two
speeches is all one, Faith alone doeth
justifie: And, it is certaine that we are
not iustified but by faith in lesus
Christ. Je addeth the example of the
Apostles, And we have beleeved in le
sus Christ, that we mioht be justified
by faith in Jesus Christ : and not by
the workes of the lawe. In like man
ner also, Peter argueth by an erample
in the Actes of the Apostles, and saith,
wee beleeve that through the grace
of our Lord lesus Christ wee shall be
saved, even as they. Aets. 15.
Moreover, in the very same chapter
to the Gala. he saith: I despise not the
grace of God: for if righteousnesse
come of the lawe then Christ is dead
in vaine. For if we in our selves had
had any thing whereby we might bee
saved, what needed the sonne of God to
take our flesh, to suffer and to die: But
for because the sonne of God being in
carnate, did suffer and die, and died not
in vaine : therefore in our flesh there
was nothing that could obtaine salva
tion for mankinde. Wherefore the on
ly sonne of God is our saviour for e
ver: and by true faith maketh us par
takers of his salvation.
Paule in the very beginning of his
Epistle to the Bom, doth prove that al
men are sinners, that in men there re
maineth no strength for them to bee
saved by, and that the lawe of God it
life and salvation of the Gentils. This
life and salvation hee doth communi
cate to us, not by the lawe or through
circumcision: but by faith in Christ,
Therefore faith alone doth justifie,
This may be proved by the example of
Cornelius the Centuris, who as soone
as S. Peter had preached unto him, &
he once beleeved, was by & by justified
when as yet he had not received ciresi
cision, or the law, when as yet hee had
not satrificed, nor merited righteous
nes by any worke ye he did: For he was
freely justified in faith through Jesus
Christ. For Peter concluded his Ser
mon to him in these wordes. To this
Christ doe all the Prophetes give wit
nesse, that through his name whosoe,
ver beleeveth in him shall receive re
mission of sinnes. After all this, the A
ostle Paul bringeth foorth in that no
table and singular example of our fa
ther Abraha, teaching by what means
our father Abraham was justified. For
this being once truely declared, it can
not chose but be plaine & manifest to e
verie one, by what means Gods wil is
to justifie all men. For the sonnes can
not be justified any other way than the
father before them was justified. Abra
ham therfore was not iustified by cir
cumcision or receiving of the sacra
ment. For it is said that he was justi
fied before he was circumcised.
Afterward was added the signe of
circumcision, as the seale of the righte
ousnesse of faith, that is the signe or
sealing, that al the seed of Abraham is
justified by faith. The same our father
Abraham was not iustified by ye lawe,
For the law was ar30. yeeres added to
the promise, not to take away sinne or
to worke justification, but to make sin
appeare, & to make us altogether emp
ty, & when we are once made empty, to
send and as it were compell us to flye
to Christ. Againe, Abraham was not
justified by his works, And yet in that
most excellent Patriarch are found to
be good workes, yea and those too good
workes of true faith, which are both
notalbe and many in number, such and
so many as you shall scarcely finde in
any other
Neverthelesse yet the Apostle saith,
what shall we say then that Abraham
our father as perteyning to the flesh,
who l say is our father touthing the
flesh, did merit or finde, for both those
significations hath the Ereeke word
jvmmthia. For, if Abraham were justi
fied by workes, then hath he to boast
but not before God. For God is onely
just et he that onely justifieth. All men
are corrupt yea eve Abraham is a sin
ner & every man stadeth in need of the
glory of God. For which cause also the
Prophet did plainely forbid to boast in
any thing but in the mercy of God.
Wherefore, Abraham boasted not a
gainst God: he acknowledged himelfe
to be a sinner, and that he was to be
justified freely, and not for his owne
merits sake. The Apostle goeth forth
and saith. For what saith the Scrip
ture. Abraham beleeved in God,
and it was reckoned unto him for
righteousnesse. Two thinges are
here affirmed. First that Abraham
beleeved in God, Secondly that that
was imputed to him for righteousnes,

True faith is the welspring and
roote of all vertues, and good workes,
and first of all it satisfieth the minde
and desire of man, and maketh it quiet
and joytull,
For the Lorde in the Gospell saith:
I am the bread of life: he that com
meth to mee, shall not hunger: and he
that beleeveth in me, shall not thirst at
anie time For what can hee desire
more, which doth alreadie feele that
by true faith hee possesseth the verie
sonne of God, in whome are all the
heavenly treasures, and in whome
is all fulnesse and grace: Our con
sciences are made cleare and quiet,
so soone as we perceive, that by true
faith Christ the sonne of God, is al
together ours, that he hath appeased
the father in our behalfe, that he doth
nowe stande in the presence of the fa
ther, and maketh intercession to him
for us And for that cause saith Paul:
Beeing justified by faith wee have
peace with God through our Lorde
Jesus Christ. Through the same
Christ also by faith wee have a free
passage unto the Father There
fore wee praye to the Father in this
Sonnes name, and at his hande wee
obtaine al things that are availeable
to our behoofe. Verie well therefore
saide the Apostle John. And this is the
confidence that we have in him, that
if we aske anie thing according o his
will hee heareth us. And if we knowe
that hee heareth us whatsoever wee
aske, wee knowe also that wee have
the petitions that we requested at his
hands,
They that want faith, doe neither
pray to God, nor yet receive of him
the things that are for their welfare,
Moreover, faith maketh us acceptable
to God, and doth command us to have
an cie to the well using of Gods goo
gifts. Faith causeth us not to faynt in
tribulations: yea also by fayth wee o
vercome the world, the flesh, the divel,
and all adversities.
As the Apostle Iohn sayth, For all
that is borne of God, overcommeth

Paul saith, Some were racked, not
caring by faith to be set at libertie, that
they might obtaine a better resurrecti
on. Other some were tried with mocks
and stripes, with fetters and imprison
mentes, were stoned, were hewed in
peeces, were slaine with the edge of
the sworde: they wandred in sheepes
gkinnes and goates akinnes, comfort
lesse, oppressed, aftlicted of whome
the worlde was not worthie wande
ring in deserts and mountames, and in
the dennes and caves of the earth. For,
the Lorde him selfe in the Gospell
sayde: This spake I unto you, that yee
might have peace in me. In the world
yee have afllietion, but be of good
confidence, I have overcome the
worlde.
Faith therefore both shall be, and
is the force and strength of patience.
Patience is the proppe, uplifting and
preseruation of hope, Of faith spring
eth charitie. Charitie is the fulfilling
of the lawe, which contayneth in it
the summe of all good workes. But
unlesse wee have a true fayth in God,
there is no charitie in us. Everie one
that loveth him that begate, sayth
John the Apostle, loveth him also that
is borne of him. The houre is past a
good while since, and no man is able
in many houres, so substantially as it
requireth, to declare the whole effect
of faith,
Hee have heard (dearely beloved)
that true faith is the justification of
the Church or faithfull of God, that it
is I say the forgivenesse of al sinnes, a
receiving into the grace of God, a ta
king by adoption into the number of
the Sonnes of God, an allured and
blessed sanctification, and finally the
welspring of all good workes. Let us
therefore in true faith pray to God the
father in the name of our Lorde Jesus
Christ, that he will vouchafe to sil our
harts with this true faith, that in this
present worlde being ioyned to him in
faith we may serve him as we ought,
and after our departure out of this life,
we may for ever live with him in who
we believe. To him be praise and glo
rie for ever. Amen
